The cost of sea level rise is just one of a large number of very serious impacts of climate change. It is quite disturbing, to put it mildly, that the breathtaking scope of the developing problem is familiar to so few people. The cumulative effect will almost certainly be beyond the capacity of our current institutions to handle. Societies around the world will doubtless be destabilized and it is naive to think that we will be immune.

But we still have some limited time in which to make choices. Continuing on our current course is very liable to lead to catastrophic consequences that will produce fundamental disruption. Taking decisive action now to reduce fossil fuel consumption through conservation and alternative energy development will reduce the severity of coming challenges at least to some extent.

Please ask yourself these questions: Can you really enumerate the problems that we will be facing due to climate change? Do you have a sense of the cost both in monetary and human terms. If you can answer yes to these questions then either you are focused on taking whatever constructive actions you can or you are indeed cynical. Alternatively, if you cannot answer yes to these questions then I urge you to educate yourself now. As an example, it's been estimated that $2.5 trillion in real estate assets are at risk in California alone. That's trillion, not billion. And this is only one of a very long list of profound impacts here and around the world.

recess: "to stop regular activity in a court of law or in a government for a usually short period of time"

Can you explain how you derived $1/{2^{(i-j+1)}}$? I'm having trouble fitting this with the results I'm seeing. For example, if i=3 and j=1 and we each have 3 cards, then the only way I can win that trick is if I have the three highest cards in the deck. That happens one time out of 20, I think.
D-Ferg you're right, my probability calculations are incorrect.  I'll try to fix this - thanks.

Suppose our team A has cards $A_i$ and opposing team B has cards $B_i$, with $A_i$>$A_j$ and $B_i$>$B_j$ whenever i is less than or equal to j. Now it will be helpful to calculate the expected value to team A for each battle of $A_i$ vs $B_j$. We can do this calculation by drawing a grid with the A's on one axis and the B's on the other axis, filling in the boxes on the main diagonal with "1/2", and then completing the rest of the grid.

If i = j, then the expected value to team A of $A_i$ vs $B_j$ is exactly 1/2.

If i > j then the expected value is $1/{2^{(i-j+1)}}$.

If i < j then the expected value is $1 - 1/{2^{(j-i+1)}}$.

The expected value for each trick for each "favored card" should not be hard to calculate. Using Hans' definition for s, we get s = j - i. Also, there are n - s such tricks. So the total expected value for all the favored card tricks should be $(n - s) \times (1 - 1/{2^{(s+1)}})$.

The expected value calculation for the "sacrificed cards" is a little more complex, since we place these cards in reverse order. As far as I can tell, the total expected value of the sacrificed cards is $(1/8)(1+{2^{(-2)}}+{2^{(-4)}}+ ... +{2^{(2-2s)}})$.

I haven't worked out the rest, but hope this is a helpful start.
